case_vignette: A 40-year-old Japanese woman presents to her primary care doctor with complaints of headache and palpitations. She is a business analyst who was recently promoted to a senior role at her company. She has noticed that she feels more anxious at work and at home with her kids. She has been trying to eat to keep her strength up, but thinks that tea and soup are easier to digest given her anxiety. She said that years ago she had her tonsil size reduced by radiation because "that's what the doctor recommended." On physical exam, there is a palpable, non-tender swelling in the front of her neck that moves with swallowing. There is no cervical lymphadenopathy. An ultrasound of the thyroid reveals a large, hypoechoic nodule shown in Figure A. The doctor refers the patient to a specialist for a fine-needle aspiration biopsy.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Endocrinology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having headaches and palpitations.
Have you noticed any sweating or weight loss along with these symptoms?
No, I haven't noticed any sweating or weight loss.

Do you have a history of high blood pressure or heart disease?

[The patient replied: "No, I don't have a history of high blood pressure or heart disease."]

Do you take any medications regularly?

[The patient replied: "No, I don't take any medications regularly."]

Do you have a family history of thyroid issues?

[The patient replied: "Yes, my mother has an overactive thyroid."]

Final Diagnosis: Graves' Disease.
